WRITING.TITLE: [Differential equations \ calculus]
WRITING.TEXT:
This relates to a container into which liquid is flowing at a constant rate. A hole in the container allows liquid to flow out at the same time.
It is fairly straightforward to derive an expression relating the height of the water to the rate at which water is flowing out (the outflow rate being proportional to the squareroot of the height of the water). However I'm trying to derive an expression to findthe time it takes to fill the container to it's optimum height (e.g. when the input flow rate matches the output flow rate), and this is the part I'm having real trouble with. Any tips\suggested directions appreciated.
Thanks!

Thanks! I clearly need to work on my integration.
Any tips on integrating that expression? It's not covered by the standard integrals I know. I've used WolframAlpha, which gives an [answer](http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=integrate+%281%2F%28A-Bx%5E0.5%29%29+dx), but I'd like to be able to work it through for myself.
edit: I'm trying to a result giving x as a function of t, if that helps.
Ah that's why the italics appeared. Cheers :-)

90% is 0.9*, so 90% of x = 0.9*x. so 0.9*x=6.32
Divide both sides by 0.9 to get x e.g. x=6.32/0.9
What's the question? Can you just not evaluate the expression to find C?

WRITING.TITLE: [Calculus] Differential equation exact solution
WRITING.TEXT:
Given a differential equation in the form
dx/dt=a-bx^(0.5)
I've tried the integrating factor here e.g. e^-bx but I end up lost - I've been told that the solution is relatively simple, which makes me think I'm doing something drastically wrong.
I cannot see this is a seperation of variables equation either as there is no function of t, f(t), involved. Even I take f(t) to be 1 (e.g. a constant), I cannot seperate the V on the RHS.

Still tripping balls after a 2 day acid binge, I suddenly remembered a job trial I'd arranged at a local bar. Propelled along to start this job by an overactive sense of responsibility, whilst not actually being able to see\focus properly, I rocked up to begin my evening shift.
Never worked behind a bar before, and remarkably held it together when shown how to pull pints. When I tried pulling pints for customers though, as soon as I started, the glass started overflowing, so I stopped. My vision stopped messing about, I looked again, and the glass had only a drop of beer and was nowhere near overflowing, so I tried again. Rinse and repeat. After spending what seemed like an hour, but was probably 5 mins, sorting just one drink, I decided bar work wasn't for me. Told my manager I want feeling too good, and staggered off home. For more acid.

UK here: I took my bank to court around 8 years ago, claiming that all of the bank charges they levied on me were disproportionate, and excessively covered their costs beyond a reasonable limit. Statute of limitations meant I could claim back only 6 years, but I won and the bank had to pay interest as well. Took back around 4000. Now my wage at the time was poor, and one charge led to another, which snowballed leading to yet more charges. Of course, there was a degree of responsibility on me, but I was not helped (until I met a reasonable branch manager) in the least by my bank. Felt good to do something about it, hut a shame that banking practises can lead to this action being necessary to begin with.

I've only the one stem alas - was just trying to find a use for these old bits. Think I'll probably buy some proper tubing though and rig something. Cheers for the idea though - will probably go with a two-stem style approach just with different fixtures.
Thanks, I think you're probably right! If only I'd kept my Planet-X DH bars; 5mm thick. No doubt they'd have been strong enough, but these AtomLabs are noticeably skinnier.

Thanks, that's a good point - I was thinking of attaching the bars to a large section of 4"x4" and then having it rest on the loft floor (through a trapdoor). I think you're right that twisting could be a problem. Also a bit unsure of the strength of them in light /u/webbot25k's comment above.
I'll rethink this plan I think!

WRITING.TITLE: Recycling old handlebars into pull-up bars (strength question)
WRITING.TEXT: I've got some old (although barely used) AtomLabs handlebars. Am thinking, along with a solid lump of metal GT handlebars stem, of turning these bars into a pull-up bar at home. Just wondering if engineered to support this much weight compared to their daily use on a bike). Anyone tried this? Know if they'll be strong enough? Otherwise I'll try it out and report back!

Quite; UK degrees are classed as 1, 2.1, 2.2 or 3. The 1 and 2.2 commonly referred to respectively as a Damian (Hirst) and a Desmond (Tutu) - cockney rhyming slang innit - First and Two Two. Source: live in UK, studying at Open University part time, working fulltime.
Op could be referring to another qualification though: A-levels results are ranked by letter

There wouldn't even be any stars in front of a planet; that would imply they're between the viewer and the distant planet - either the stars would be very tiny (but still big enough to gravitationally destroy both planets), or the planet fucking massive (so big, it would turn into a star, and then consume both planets).
That said, the pic is fracking awesome.
